~Seeking~ is a more formal synonym for 'looking for'.

cards.correctAnswer: Everyone says I take after my grandfather.
cards.hint: 'Take after' is unique because it can refer to inheriting both physical appearance and personality traits from a relative.

content.value:
[Take after] means to resemble an older family member in looks or character.

~Look like~ only refers to physical appearance.
~Act like~ only refers to behavior.

cards.correctAnswer: I can't think of his name right now.
cards.hint: Use 'think of' when an idea or piece of information comes into your mind.

content.value:
[Think of] is used here to mean recalling a piece of information.

~Remember~ and ~recall~ are excellent, more formal synonyms. 'Think of' is very common in everyday speech.

sentenceParts.prefix: He was so tired that he
sentenceParts.suffix: as soon as his head hit the pillow.

cards.correctAnswer: He was so tired that he fell asleep as soon as his head hit the pillow.
cards.hint: 'Fall asleep' refers to the involuntary action of beginning to sleep.

content.value:
[Fell asleep] describes the moment sleep begins.

~Went to sleep~ implies a conscious decision to try to sleep.
~Passed out~ means to lose consciousness, often due to medical reasons or exhaustion, which is much stronger than simply falling asleep.

sentenceParts.suffix: going out; I'd rather stay home.

cards.correctAnswer: I don't feel like going out; I'd rather stay home.
cards.hint: The expression 'feel like' must be followed by a noun or a gerund (-ing form).

content.value:
[Feel like] is an idiom expressing a desire or inclination.

~Want to~ is incorrect because it must be followed by a base verb ('go'), not a gerund ('going').
~Have the energy for~ is a plausible reason but not a direct synonym.

cards.correctAnswer: It's hard to get by on such a low salary.
cards.hint: 'Get by' means to manage to live with just enough money for your basic needs.

content.value:
[Get by] specifically means to manage financially with difficulty.

~Live~ is too general.
~Survive~ is a good synonym but 'get by' is the common phrasal verb that perfectly captures the sense of having just enough.

sentenceParts.prefix: After the argument, they tried to

cards.correctAnswer: After the argument, they tried to get on with their lives.
cards.hint: To 'get on with' something means to continue doing it, especially after an interruption.

content.value:
[Get on with] means to continue with your life or work.

~Continue~ is a good synonym.
~Move on with~ is also very similar, but 'get on with' is a very common British English phrasal verb for this context.

cards.correctAnswer: We finally got rid of the mice in the attic.
cards.hint: The three-part phrase 'get rid of' means to eliminate or dispose of something unwanted.

content.value:
[Got rid of] means to remove or discard something completely.

~Eliminated~ and ~removed~ are correct, more formal synonyms. 'Got rid of' is extremely common in everyday language.

sentenceParts.prefix: Even when things get difficult, just

cards.correctAnswer: Even when things get difficult, just keep going.
cards.hint: 'Keep going' is an encouraging phrase meaning to persevere and not give up.

content.value:
[Keep going] is an idiom that means to continue, especially in the face of adversity.

~Don't stop~ is a direct command.
~Persist~ is a more formal verb meaning the same thing.

cards.correctAnswer: It looks like it's going to rain.
cards.hint: 'Looks like' is used to make a judgment or prediction based on visual evidence.

content.value:
[Looks like] is used to express an opinion based on appearance.

~Seems like~ is based on a general impression, not just visual cues.
~Appears that~ is a more formal alternative.

cards.category: BONUS: PHRASAL VERBS ESPECIALIZADOS EN TECH
cards.correctAnswer: His presentation helped the team buy into the new workflow.
cards.hint: To 'buy into' an idea means to fully believe in it and support it.

content.value:
[Buy into] means to become convinced of the value or truth of an idea.

~Accept~ and ~agree to~ are more neutral. 'Buy into' implies genuine belief and enthusiasm.

cards.category: BONUS: PHRASAL VERBS ESPECIALIZADOS EN TECH

sentenceParts.prefix: Due to unexpected delays, they decided to

cards.correctAnswer: Due to unexpected delays, they decided to push back the product launch.
cards.hint: 'Push back' and 'put off' are common phrasal verbs for postponing something.

content.value:
[Push back] means to postpone to a later date. [Put off] is an excellent and equally correct synonym.

~Reschedule~ is the more formal, non-phrasal verb for this action.

cards.category: BONUS: PHRASAL VERBS ESPECIALIZADOS EN TECH

sentenceParts.suffix: easily as the number of users grows.

cards.correctAnswer: The application was designed to scale up easily as the number of users grows.
cards.hint: In technology, 'scale up' means to handle increased load or demand without a loss in performance.

content.value:
[Scale up] is a technical term for increasing capacity to meet demand.

~Grow~ and ~expand~ are more general terms. 'Scale up' specifically relates to a system's ability to perform well under greater load.

cards.category: BONUS: PHRASAL VERBS ESPECIALIZADOS EN TECH

sentenceParts.suffix: a lot of emails every morning.

cards.correctAnswer: I have to deal with a lot of emails every morning.
cards.hint: 'Deal with' is a general phrasal verb for managing tasks, problems, or correspondence.

content.value:
[Deal with] means to take the necessary actions regarding something. It can include reading, replying, deleting, and organizing.

~Answer~ is only one possible action.
~Process~ is a good synonym but 'deal with' is more common in everyday speech.

sentenceParts.prefix: The tension in the room was

cards.correctAnswer: The tension in the room was building up as we waited.
cards.hint: Use 'build up' to describe something that increases gradually over time, like an emotion or pressure.

content.value:
[Building up] means to increase in quantity or intensity over a period.

~Growing~ and ~increasing~ are correct verbs, but 'building up' creates a stronger image of gradual accumulation.

cards.correctAnswer: The party started to wind down around midnight.
cards.hint: When an event 'winds down', its activity and energy decrease as it comes to an end.

content.value:
[Wind down] means to gradually become less active and end.

~End~ is more abrupt.
~Slow down~ refers to a reduction in speed, while 'wind down' refers to overall activity.

cards.correctAnswer: Hurry up! We're running out of time.
cards.hint: The phrase 'run out of' is used when a finite resource, like time or milk, is almost completely used up.

content.value:
[Running out] is the phrasal verb meaning to have less and less of a resource until none is left.

~Losing~ time is not the correct collocation.
~Wasting~ time implies using it unwisely, which is a different meaning.

cards.correctAnswer: Her career really took off after she won the award.
cards.hint: When a career or project 'takes off', it suddenly becomes very successful.

content.value:
[Took off] is an idiom meaning to become successful or popular very quickly.

~Started~ is too neutral.
~Blossomed~ is a good metaphorical synonym, but 'took off' suggests more speed and rapid success.

cards.correctAnswer: What time did you show up at the party?
cards.hint: Using 'show up' instead of 'arrive' can sometimes imply a casualness or a slight surprise about the arrival.

content.value:
[Show up] is a common, slightly informal phrasal verb for 'arrive'.

~Arrive~ and ~get there~ are correct, more neutral alternatives. 'Show up' is very common in spoken English.

cards.correctAnswer: Children often make up imaginary friends.
cards.hint: To 'make up' something means to invent it, and it's often used for stories, excuses, or imaginary things.

content.value:
[Make up] means to create from imagination.

~Invent~ is a good synonym but often relates to physical objects or more complex lies.
~Imagine~ is the mental process, while 'make up' is the act of creation.

sentenceParts.prefix: Here's a joke to help you

cards.correctAnswer: Here's a joke to help you cheer up.
cards.hint: This phrasal verb means to make someone feel happier.

content.value:
[Cheer up] means to become or make someone happier.

~Look up~ means to search for information.
~Bring up~ means to mention a topic.

sentenceParts.prefix: She was feeling sad, so her friends took her out to

cards.correctAnswer: She was feeling sad, so her friends took her out to cheer her up.
cards.hint: This is the separable version of 'cheer up', where the object goes in the middle.

content.value:
[Cheer her up] is the correct separable form for making someone happier.

~Pick her up~ means to collect someone in a vehicle.
~Lift her up~ means to physically raise someone.

sentenceParts.prefix: We took a wrong turn and

cards.correctAnswer: We took a wrong turn and ended up in a completely different town.
cards.hint: Use 'end up' to describe a final result or location that was not originally planned.

content.value:
[Ended up] describes the final, often unexpected, result of a situation or journey.

~Showed up~ means to arrive.
~Came up~ means something appeared unexpectedly.

sentenceParts.prefix: He never wanted to be a manager, but that's how he

cards.correctAnswer: He never wanted to be a manager, but that's how he ended up.
cards.hint: 'End up' can also describe a final state or condition, not just a location.

content.value:
[Ended up] describes reaching a final, unplanned state or role.

~Grew up~ means to mature into an adult.
~Set up~ means to establish or arrange something.

cards.correctAnswer: The kids used up all the cookies.
cards.hint: To 'use up' something means to consume it completely so that nothing is left.

content.value:
[Used up] means to finish the entire supply of something.

~Ate on~ and ~finished out~ are not correct phrasal verbs in this context.

sentenceParts.suffix: all my energy for the day.

cards.correctAnswer: The long meeting used up all my energy for the day.
cards.hint: 'Use up' can apply to intangible resources like energy, time, or patience, not just physical items.

content.value:
[Used up] means to consume a resource completely.

~Took out~ means to remove.
~Ran down~ can mean to lose power, but 'used up' fits better for personal energy.

sentenceParts.prefix: He argued for a while, but he finally
sentenceParts.suffix: when he saw he was wrong.

cards.correctAnswer: He argued for a while, but he finally backed down when he saw he was wrong.
cards.hint: To 'back down' means to withdraw from a position or argument.

content.value:
[Backed down] means to admit defeat or withdraw your claim in a conflict.

~Gave up~ means to quit an effort.
~Fell over~ means to fall to the ground.

sentenceParts.suffix: on its demand for a pay raise.

cards.correctAnswer: The union refused to back down on its demand for a pay raise.
cards.hint: 'Back down' is often used in negotiations to mean withdrawing a demand.

content.value:
[Back down] means to withdraw from a confrontation or demand.

~Slow down~ means to reduce speed.
~Cut off~ means to stop a supply or interrupt.

sentenceParts.prefix: After traveling for years, they decided to

cards.correctAnswer: After traveling for years, they decided to settle down and buy a house.
cards.hint: To 'settle down' means to adopt a more stable and routine lifestyle, often involving marriage and a permanent home.

content.value:
[Settle down] means to begin to live a quiet life in one place.

~Calm down~ means to become less angry or excited.
~Sit down~ means to take a seat.

sentenceParts.prefix: The teacher told the excited children to

cards.correctAnswer: The teacher told the excited children to settle down and listen.
cards.hint: 'Settle down' can also mean to become quiet and calm after being active or noisy.

content.value:
[Settle down] means for a group to become quiet and orderly.

~Wind down~ means to relax after activity.
~Break down~ means to stop functioning or to cry.

sentenceParts.prefix: We don't cook much on Fridays; we usually

cards.correctAnswer: We don't cook much on Fridays; we usually eat out.
cards.hint: To 'eat out' means to have a meal at a restaurant instead of at home.

content.value:
[Eat out] means to dine at a restaurant.

~Take out~ means to buy food at a restaurant and bring it home to eat.
~Give out~ means to distribute.

cards.correctAnswer: It's a special occasion, let's eat out at that fancy Italian place.
cards.hint: Remember, 'eat out' refers to the action of going to a restaurant for a meal.

content.value:
[Eat out] is the phrasal verb for dining in a restaurant.

~Sort out~ means to organize or solve.
~Check out~ means to examine something interesting.

sentenceParts.suffix: at the park or the mall.

cards.correctAnswer: On weekends, we like to hang out at the park or the mall.
cards.hint: To 'hang out' is an informal way to say 'spend time relaxing or socializing'.

content.value:
[Hang out] means to spend leisure time with no specific activity.

~Get out~ means to leave a place.
~Stand out~ means to be noticeable.

cards.correctAnswer: He's going to hang out with his friends after school.
cards.hint: 'Hang out with' someone means to spend time with them socially.

content.value:
[Hang out] means to socialize informally.

~Fall out~ means to have an argument and stop being friends.
~Work out~ means to exercise.

sentenceParts.prefix: You filled out the form, but you

cards.correctAnswer: You filled out the form, but you left out the last question.
cards.hint: To 'leave out' something means to omit it or not include it.

content.value:
[Left out] means to omit.

~Cut out~ means to stop consuming something.
~Ran out~ means to have no more of something.

sentenceParts.suffix: when his friends went to the movies without him.

cards.correctAnswer: He felt left out when his friends went to the movies without him.
cards.hint: To 'feel left out' is an emotional state of feeling excluded from a group or activity.

content.value:
[Left out] means excluded.

~Put out~ can mean annoyed or to extinguish a fire.
~Dropped out~ means to quit school or a competition.

sentenceParts.suffix: in the middle of the night.

cards.correctAnswer: The fire alarm went off in the middle of the night.
cards.hint: For an alarm, 'go off' means to suddenly start making noise.

content.value:
[Went off] means to activate suddenly (for an alarm, a bomb).

~Turned on~ implies someone activated it intentionally.
~Shut off~ means to deactivate.

sentenceParts.prefix: Don't eat that yogurt; it smells like it has

cards.correctAnswer: Don't eat that yogurt; it smells like it has gone off.
cards.hint: For food, 'go off' (especially in British English) means it has spoiled and is no longer good to eat.

content.value:
[Gone off] means food has spoiled.

~Run out~ means there is none left.
~Turned bad~ is a correct description, but 'gone off' is the common phrasal verb.

cards.correctAnswer: The pain medication should wear off after a few hours.
cards.hint: When the effect of something (like a drug or a feeling) 'wears off', it gradually disappears.

content.value:
[Wear off] means to gradually stop having an effect.

~Give out~ means to stop working or to distribute.
~Pass away~ is a euphemism for 'to die'.

sentenceParts.prefix: The initial excitement of the new job started to

cards.correctAnswer: The initial excitement of the new job started to wear off.
cards.hint: 'Wear off' is perfect for describing a feeling or novelty that lessens over time.

content.value:
[Wear off] means for a feeling to gradually disappear.

~Fade away~ and ~die down~ are very similar and also good choices, but 'wear off' is particularly common for feelings and effects.

sentenceParts.suffix: a moment while I check your file.

cards.correctAnswer: Please hold on a moment while I check your file.
cards.hint: 'Hold on' is a common, informal way to ask someone to wait for a short time.

content.value:
[Hold on] is a phrasal verb meaning 'wait'.

~Wait up~ means to wait for someone to come home before going to bed.
~Stand by~ means to wait and be ready for action.

cards.correctAnswer: Hold on! You're driving too fast.
cards.hint: In this context, 'Hold on' is an exclamation used to tell someone to stop or wait, often because of surprise or danger.

content.value:
[Hold on] is used here as an exclamation to mean 'stop' or 'wait'.

~Carry on~ and ~go on~ both mean 'continue', which is the opposite of the intended meaning.

cards.correctAnswer: Don't stop now, keep on trying!
cards.hint: 'Keep on' means to continue doing something without stopping, often with persistence.

content.value:
[Keep on] (followed by a gerund) means to persevere or continue.

~Hold on~ means to wait.
~Stay at~ is for location.

sentenceParts.prefix: I told him to be quiet, but he just

cards.correctAnswer: I told him to be quiet, but he just kept on talking.
cards.hint: 'Keep on' can imply continuing an action in a persistent, sometimes annoying, way.

content.value:
[Kept on] means continued, often against advice or expectations.

~Stayed on~ means remained.
~Focused on~ means concentrated.

cards.category: Phrasal Verbs with AWAY, BACK, & AROUND

sentenceParts.prefix: I lent him money a month ago, and he still hasn't

cards.correctAnswer: I lent him money a month ago, and he still hasn't paid me back.
cards.hint: The phrasal verb 'pay back' means to return money that you borrowed.

content.value:
[Paid me back] is the correct separable phrasal verb for returning a loan.

~Given me back~ could be used for an object, but 'pay' is specific to money.
~Sent me back~ is incorrect.

cards.category: Phrasal Verbs with AWAY, BACK, & AROUND

sentenceParts.prefix: She helped me when I was in trouble, and I'll

cards.correctAnswer: She helped me when I was in trouble, and I'll pay her back one day.
cards.hint: 'Pay someone back' can also mean to do something good for them in return for a past favor.

content.value:
[Pay her back] can idiomatically mean to return a favor.

~Get her back~ can mean to get revenge, which is negative.
~Help her back~ is not a standard phrasal verb.

cards.category: Phrasal Verbs with AWAY, BACK, & AROUND

sentenceParts.prefix: The storm is getting worse; we should

cards.correctAnswer: The storm is getting worse; we should turn back.
cards.hint: To 'turn back' means to abandon a journey and return to where you started.

content.value:
[Turn back] means to return in the direction you came from.

~Go away~ is a command to leave.
~Get off~ means to disembark from a bus, train, etc.

cards.category: Phrasal Verbs with AWAY, BACK, & AROUND

sentenceParts.suffix: now; we have to finish what we started.

cards.correctAnswer: It's too late to turn back now; we have to finish what we started.
cards.hint: Metaphorically, 'turn back' can mean to abandon a project or course of action.

content.value:
[Turn back] means to abandon an undertaking.

~Give up~ means to quit trying.
~Back down~ means to withdraw from a conflict or demand.

sentenceParts.suffix: this email for me to check for errors?

cards.correctAnswer: Could you read over this email for me to check for errors?
cards.hint: To 'read over' something means to read it from beginning to end to check for mistakes or understanding.

content.value:
[Read over] means to review a document by reading it.

~Look for~ means to search for something.
~Figure out~ means to solve or understand a problem.

cards.correctAnswer: He quickly read over the contract before signing it.
cards.hint: 'Read over' is similar to 'go over' or 'look over', implying a review.

content.value:
[Read over] means to read something to check it, often quickly.

~Got through~ means to finish or endure.
~Thought up~ is not a standard phrasal verb; 'think up' means to invent.

sentenceParts.prefix: It's a big decision; you should

cards.correctAnswer: It's a big decision; you should think it over carefully.
cards.hint: To 'think something over' means to consider it very carefully before making a decision. It is separable.

content.value:
[Think it over] means to consider a decision carefully.

~Make it up~ means to invent something or reconcile.
~Get it on~ is an informal idiom meaning to start something.

cards.correctAnswer: I need some time to think over your proposal.
cards.hint: 'Think over' is often used for decisions, proposals, and offers that require careful consideration.

content.value:
[Think over] means to carefully consider.

~Look into~ means to investigate.
~Go after~ means to pursue.

sentenceParts.prefix: The final exam was so difficult, I didn't think I would

cards.correctAnswer: The final exam was so difficult, I didn't think I would get through it.
cards.hint: To 'get through' something means to finish or endure a difficult task or experience.

content.value:
[Get through] means to successfully complete or survive something challenging.

~Pass by~ means to go past something.
~Come over~ means to visit someone's house.

sentenceParts.prefix: I tried calling you, but I couldn't

cards.correctAnswer: I tried calling you, but I couldn't get through. The line was busy.
cards.hint: In telecommunications, 'get through' means to successfully make contact with someone by phone.

content.value:
[Get through] means to establish a phone connection.

~Call up~ means to telephone someone.
~Reach out~ means to try to communicate with someone.

sentenceParts.suffix: in yourself if you want to succeed.

cards.correctAnswer: You have to believe in yourself if you want to succeed.
cards.hint: To 'believe in' someone or something means to have faith in their abilities or in the truth of an idea.

content.value:
[Believe in] means to have confidence in the existence or goodness of something.

~Count on~ means to rely on.
~Think of~ means to have an opinion or recall.

cards.correctAnswer: Do you believe in ghosts?
cards.hint: 'Believe in' is used to ask if someone feels that something is real or exists.

content.value:
[Believe in] means to be certain that something exists.

~Know about~ means to have information.
~Think about~ means to consider.

cards.correctAnswer: A healthy smoothie typically consists of fruits, vegetables, and some liquid.
cards.hint: To 'consist of' something means to be formed or made from the things mentioned.

content.value:
[Consists of] is used to list the parts or things that something is made of.

~Is made from~ is similar but often implies a transformation.
~Includes~ suggests these are only some of the parts, not necessarily all of them.

sentenceParts.suffix: a written test and a practical demonstration.

cards.correctAnswer: The exam will consist of a written test and a practical demonstration.
cards.hint: 'Consist of' is often used to describe the components of a test, committee, or formal structure.

content.value:
[Consist of] means to be composed of different parts.

~Contain~ means to have something inside.
~Feature~ means to have as a prominent attribute.

cards.correctAnswer: She finally succeeded in getting the promotion she wanted.
cards.hint: The verb 'succeed' is followed by the preposition 'in' and a gerund (-ing verb) or noun.

content.value:
[Succeeded in] is the correct collocation for achieving a goal.

~Achieved to~ and ~managed on~ are grammatically incorrect constructions.

cards.correctAnswer: After many attempts, he succeeded in solving the puzzle.
cards.hint: Remember, 'succeed in' emphasizes the achievement after effort or difficulty.

content.value:
[Succeeded in] means to achieve the desired aim.

~Was able to~ is a correct alternative but is not a phrasal verb.
~Got through~ means to endure or finish a difficult task.

cards.correctAnswer: Watch out! There's a car coming!
cards.hint: 'Watch out' is an exclamation used to warn someone of imminent danger.

content.value:
[Watch out] is a warning to be careful.

~Look at~ is a command to direct your eyes toward something.
~See about~ means to deal with or inquire about something.

cards.correctAnswer: You should watch out for pickpockets in crowded areas.
cards.hint: 'Watch out for' means to be vigilant and aware of a potential problem or danger.

content.value:
[Watch out for] means to be careful of something.

~Look up~ means to search for information.
~Check on~ means to verify the status of something or someone.

cards.correctAnswer: His explanation didn't make sense at all. I'm still confused.
cards.hint: The expression 'make sense' means to be logical, understandable, and reasonable.

content.value:
[Make sense] is an idiom meaning to be intelligible or logical.

~Have logic~ is a literal description.
~Feel right~ refers to an intuitive feeling, not necessarily logic.

sentenceParts.prefix: Now that you explain it that way, it starts to

cards.correctAnswer: Now that you explain it that way, it starts to make sense.
cards.hint: Use 'make sense' when you finally understand something that was previously confusing.

content.value:
[Make sense] means to become understandable.

~Clear up~ means for confusion or a misunderstanding to be resolved.
~Sound good~ means an idea seems appealing.

sentenceParts.prefix: He speaks so fast it's hard to

cards.correctAnswer: He speaks so fast it's hard to catch on.
cards.hint: To 'catch on' means to understand something, especially after a period of confusion.

content.value:
[Catch on] means to begin to understand or realize something.

~Take in~ means to absorb information.
~Get it~ is an informal way to say 'understand'.

cards.correctAnswer: The new fashion trend quickly caught on with teenagers.
cards.hint: 'Catch on' can also mean to become popular or fashionable.

content.value:
[Caught on] means became popular.

~Grew up~ means matured.
~Showed up~ means arrived.

sentenceParts.prefix: The weather forecast says it will

cards.correctAnswer: The weather forecast says it will clear up later this afternoon.
cards.hint: For weather, 'clear up' means to become sunny and free of clouds or rain.

content.value:
[Clear up] means for the weather to improve.

~Clean up~ means to make tidy.
~Brighten on~ is not a correct phrasal verb.

sentenceParts.suffix: this misunderstanding before it causes problems.

cards.correctAnswer: We need to clear up this misunderstanding before it causes problems.
cards.hint: 'Clear up' can also mean to solve or explain something that is confusing.

content.value:
[Clear up] means to resolve a confusion or problem.

~Sort out~ is a very close synonym and also correct.
~Fix~ is a general verb for repairing something.

sentenceParts.prefix: Based on the evidence, we can

cards.correctAnswer: Based on the evidence, we can rule out the possibility of an accident.
cards.hint: To 'rule out' something means to decide that it is not a possible option or explanation.

content.value:
[Rule out] means to eliminate something from consideration.

~Take out~ means to remove.
~Get out~ means to leave.

sentenceParts.prefix: The doctor did some tests to

cards.correctAnswer: The doctor did some tests to rule out any serious conditions.
cards.hint: 'Rule out' is commonly used in medical and investigative contexts to eliminate possibilities.

content.value:
[Rule out] means to determine that something is not the cause of a problem.

~Find out~ means to discover.
~Check out~ means to examine.

sentenceParts.prefix: The fire in the kitchen was

cards.correctAnswer: The fire in the kitchen was brought about by a faulty wire.
cards.hint: To 'bring about' something means to cause it to happen.

content.value:
[Brought about] is a slightly more formal phrasal verb that means 'caused'.

~Set off~ means to trigger something to start, like an alarm.
~Caused~ is the non-phrasal verb equivalent.

sentenceParts.suffix: many positive changes in the company.

cards.correctAnswer: The new manager brought about many positive changes in the company.
cards.hint: 'Bring about' is often used for significant changes or results.

content.value:
[Brought about] means to cause something to happen.

~Made up~ means invented or reconciled.
~Carried on~ means continued.

sentenceParts.prefix: She's an excellent speaker who can easily

cards.correctAnswer: She's an excellent speaker who can easily get across her ideas.
cards.hint: To 'get an idea across' means to successfully communicate it so that others understand.

content.value:
[Get across] means to communicate something effectively.

~Put on~ means to wear or activate.
~Bring up~ means to mention.

sentenceParts.prefix: I tried to explain the problem, but I couldn't

cards.correctAnswer: I tried to explain the problem, but I couldn't get across how serious it was.
cards.hint: Use 'get across' when talking about the success or failure of communication.

content.value:
[Get across] means to make something understood.

~Come through~ means to survive or be delivered.
~Let on~ means to reveal a secret.

cards.category: Phrasal Verbs with AWAY, BACK, & AROUND
cards.correctAnswer: The government is trying to crack down on illegal immigration.
cards.hint: To 'crack down on' something means to start dealing with it in a more severe way.

content.value:
[Crack down on] means to enforce rules more strictly.

~Let up on~ means to be less strict.
~Come down with~ means to get sick with an illness.

cards.category: Phrasal Verbs with AWAY, BACK, & AROUND
cards.correctAnswer: The school decided to crack down on students who are late.
cards.hint: 'Crack down on' implies strict enforcement and punishment for bad behavior.

content.value:
[Crack down on] means to become more stringent.

~Look down on~ means to consider someone inferior.
~Back down from~ means to withdraw from a conflict.

cards.category: Phrasal Verbs with AWAY, BACK, & AROUND

sentenceParts.suffix: with the electrical wires; it's dangerous.

cards.correctAnswer: Don't mess around with the electrical wires; it's dangerous.
cards.hint: To 'mess around' with something means to handle it casually or playfully, often when you shouldn't.

content.value:
[Mess around] means to touch or play with something in a careless way.

~Play~ is too general.
~Work out~ means to exercise or solve.

cards.category: Phrasal Verbs with AWAY, BACK, & AROUND
cards.correctAnswer: Stop messing around and do your homework!
cards.hint: 'Mess around' can also mean to waste time doing silly or unproductive things.

content.value:
[Messing around] means to behave in a silly way or waste time.

~Hanging out~ means relaxing socially.
~Procrastinating~ is a good synonym, but 'messing around' is the more informal phrasal verb.

cards.category: Phrasal Verbs with AWAY, BACK, & AROUND

sentenceParts.prefix: When we arrived at the hotel, we started to

cards.correctAnswer: When we arrived at the hotel, we started to look around the neighborhood.
cards.hint: To 'look around' means to explore a place casually to see what is there.

content.value:
[Look around] means to explore a place you are in.

~Search~ implies you are looking for a specific thing.
~Check out~ is similar but often implies examining something specific you've already identified.

cards.category: Phrasal Verbs with AWAY, BACK, & AROUND
cards.correctAnswer: She spent the afternoon looking around the shops.
cards.hint: 'Look around' is often used for Browse in stores without a specific purchase in mind.

content.value:
[Looking around] means to browse without a specific goal.

~Shopping for~ implies you are looking for a specific item to buy.
~Going through~ means examining, but 'looking around' is more casual.

cards.correctAnswer: We need to talk over this problem together.
cards.hint: To 'talk something over' means to discuss it thoroughly to make a decision or find a solution.

content.value:
[Talk over] means to discuss a problem in detail.

~Speak about~ is more general.
~Get through~ means to endure a difficult time.

cards.correctAnswer: Before you decide, talk it over with your family.
cards.hint: 'Talk over' is a separable phrasal verb, so the object can go in the middle.

content.value:
[Talk it over] is the correct separable form for discussing something.

~Think it over~ means to consider it alone.
~Go it over~ is incorrect; the verb is 'go over'.

cards.correctAnswer: Would you like to join in our club?
cards.hint: To 'join in' means to become involved in an activity with other people.

content.value:
[Join in] means to participate in something that is already happening.

~Sign up~ means to formally register for something.
~Get with~ is not a standard phrasal verb in this context.

sentenceParts.prefix: Everyone started singing, so we decided to

cards.correctAnswer: Everyone started singing, so we decided to join in.
cards.hint: Use 'join in' when you start doing what a group of people are already doing.

content.value:
[Join in] means to participate.

~Take part~ is a good synonym but is a bit more formal.
~Enter~ is for going into a place or competition.

sentenceParts.prefix: He was injured in the first game and had to
sentenceParts.suffix: for the rest of the season.

cards.correctAnswer: He was injured in the first game and had to sit out for the rest of the season.
cards.hint: To 'sit out' an activity, like a game or a dance, means to not participate in it.

content.value:
[Sit out] means to not be involved in something.

~Stay away~ means to not go near.
~Drop out~ means to quit a competition or school permanently.

sentenceParts.prefix: I'm not feeling well; I think I'll

cards.correctAnswer: I'm not feeling well; I think I'll sit this one out.
cards.hint: 'Sit something out' is a separable phrasal verb meaning to not take part in a single event.

content.value:
[Sit this one out] is the idiomatic way to say you are not participating in one specific activity.

~Skip~ and ~miss~ are correct verbs but not phrasal verbs.

cards.correctAnswer: The new policy will bring about a lot of changes.
cards.hint: To 'bring about' means to cause something to happen.

content.value:
[Bring about] means to cause.

~Come with~ means to accompany.
~Make~ is too general.

sentenceParts.suffix: and agreed to sell the house.

cards.correctAnswer: She finally came around and agreed to sell the house.
cards.hint: To 'come around' means to change your opinion or decision because someone has persuaded you.

content.value:
[Came around] means to change one's mind.

~Gave in~ means to surrender to pressure.
~Turned up~ means to appear.

cards.correctAnswer: She works two jobs to make ends meet.
cards.hint: The idiom 'make ends meet' means to have just enough money to pay for the things you need.

content.value:
[Make ends meet] is a fixed idiom for earning just enough money to live on.

~Get by~ has a very similar meaning.
~Earn enough~ is a literal description.

sentenceParts.prefix: With rising prices, it's becoming harder to

cards.correctAnswer: With rising prices, it's becoming harder to make ends meet.
cards.hint: This idiom is very common when discussing personal finance and the cost of living.

content.value:
[Make ends meet] means to manage one's budget successfully.

~Save money~ is about putting money aside.
~Stay afloat~ is another idiom with a similar meaning of surviving financially.

sentenceParts.prefix: It took a while for the new information to

cards.correctAnswer: It took a while for the new information to sink in.
cards.hint: When a fact or idea 'sinks in', you gradually begin to understand it or realize its full meaning.

content.value:
[Sink in] means to be fully understood or realized.

~Fall down~ means to collapse.
~Go through~ means to experience or examine.

sentenceParts.prefix: He lost his job, but the reality of it hasn't

cards.correctAnswer: He lost his job, but the reality of it hasn't sunk in yet.
cards.hint: 'Sink in' is often used for shocking or significant news that is difficult to accept at first.

content.value:
[Sunk in] is the past participle form. It means the full impact hasn't been felt.

~Set in~ means to begin and seem likely to continue (like 'winter has set in').
~Come about~ means to happen.

sentenceParts.suffix: this old photo album while cleaning the attic.

cards.correctAnswer: I came across this old photo album while cleaning the attic.
cards.hint: To 'come across' something means to find it by chance.

content.value:
[Came across] means to find something or someone accidentally.

~Ran into~ is usually for people, not objects.
~Found~ is the general verb for discovering something.

cards.correctAnswer: She comes across as a very confident person.
cards.hint: To 'come across' as a certain type of person means to give a particular impression.

content.value:
[Comes across] means to seem to be or give the impression of being a certain way.

~Seems like~ is a good synonym.
~Acts like~ describes behavior, while 'comes across' describes the impression that behavior creates.

sentenceParts.suffix: with thousands of dollars in jewelry.

cards.correctAnswer: The thieves made off with thousands of dollars in jewelry.
cards.hint: To 'make off' with something means to steal it and escape.

content.value:
[Made off] means to escape with stolen goods.

~Ran away~ means to escape, but doesn't include the act of stealing.
~Took out~ means to remove.

cards.correctAnswer: A raccoon made off with our picnic basket!
cards.hint: 'Make off with' strongly emphasizes the act of escaping with something stolen.

content.value:
[Made off] is the correct phrasal verb for stealing and running away.

~Got away~ means escaped, but adding 'with' is required ('got away with').
~Stole~ is a correct verb but not a phrasal verb.

sentenceParts.suffix: all the ingredients before you start cooking.

cards.correctAnswer: It's important to get in all the ingredients before you start cooking.
cards.hint: To 'get in' a supply of something means to buy or obtain it.

content.value:
[Get in] can mean to buy a supply of something.

~Take in~ means to absorb.
~Bring in~ means to introduce.

sentenceParts.prefix: What time does the train from London

cards.correctAnswer: What time does the train from London get in?
cards.hint: For transportation like a train, plane, or bus, 'get in' is a common phrasal verb meaning 'to arrive'.

content.value:
[Get in] is a common way to talk about the arrival time of transport.

~Arrive at~ is correct but more formal.
~Come~ is too general.

sentenceParts.prefix: We need to find a way to

cards.correctAnswer: We need to find a way to get around this problem.
cards.hint: To 'get around' a problem means to find a way to avoid it or deal with it without solving it directly.

content.value:
[Get around] means to overcome or evade a difficulty.

~Avoid~ means to stay away from it.
~Solve~ means to find a direct solution.

cards.correctAnswer: It's easy to get around the city on foot.
cards.hint: 'Get around' can also mean to travel to different places within a town, city, or area.

content.value:
[Get around] means to move from place to place.

~Travel~ is a more general term.
~Move~ simply means to change position.

cards.correctAnswer: The initials 'USA' stand for the United States of America.
cards.hint: To 'stand for' something means to be an abbreviation or symbol of it.

content.value:
[Stand for] is the specific phrasal verb used for acronyms and abbreviations.

~Mean~ and ~represent~ are correct synonyms but not phrasal verbs.

cards.correctAnswer: Our company stands for quality and customer service.
cards.hint: 'Stand for' can also mean to support or represent a particular idea or set of values.

content.value:
[Stands for] means to represent a core belief or principle.

~Believes in~ means to have faith in.
~Supports~ means to help or endorse.

sentenceParts.prefix: She was late for the meeting, but she
sentenceParts.suffix: it by staying late to finish the work.

cards.correctAnswer: She was late for the meeting, but she made up for it by staying late to finish the work.
cards.hint: To 'make up for' something means to compensate for a mistake or a negative situation by doing something good.

content.value:
[Made up for] is a three-part phrasal verb meaning to compensate.

~Compensated~ is a more formal synonym.
~Fixed~ means repaired.

cards.correctAnswer: His enthusiasm helps to make up for his lack of experience.
cards.hint: 'Make up for' is often used when a positive quality compensates for a negative one.

content.value:
[Make up for] means to provide a good balance against something negative.

~Balance~ is a good synonym.
~Hide~ means to conceal.

sentenceParts.prefix: Don't stop working. You need to
sentenceParts.suffix: if you want to meet the deadline.

cards.correctAnswer: Don't stop working. You need to press on if you want to meet the deadline.
cards.hint: To 'press on' means to continue doing something in a determined way, despite difficulties.

content.value:
[Press on] means to continue with determination.

~Carry on~ and ~keep going~ are very similar, but 'press on' often implies more difficulty and determination.

sentenceParts.prefix: Despite the bad weather, the hikers decided to

cards.correctAnswer: Despite the bad weather, the hikers decided to press on.
cards.hint: 'Press on' emphasizes continuing forward in the face of obstacles.

content.value:
[Press on] means to continue a journey with resolve.

~Go ahead~ means to proceed or start.
~Move up~ means to advance in position.

sentenceParts.suffix: in the middle of my sentence.

cards.correctAnswer: The argument started because he cut me off in the middle of my sentence.
cards.hint: To 'cut someone off' means to interrupt them while they are speaking.

content.value:
[Cut me off] is the separable phrasal verb for interrupting someone's speech.

~Broke me up~ is incorrect here; 'break up' means to end a relationship.
~Stopped me~ is a literal description.

sentenceParts.prefix: After the scandal, the politician was forced to

cards.correctAnswer: After the scandal, the politician was forced to pull out of the race.
cards.hint: To 'pull out' of something (like a competition, deal, or event) means to withdraw from it.

content.value:
[Pull out] means to withdraw from an activity or agreement.

~Drop out~ is similar but is more commonly used for school.
~Back down~ means to yield in an argument.

sentenceParts.suffix: the scandal, but the media found out.

cards.correctAnswer: The government tried to play down the scandal, but the media found out.
cards.hint: To 'play down' something means to try to make it seem less important or serious than it really is.

content.value:
[Play down] means to minimize the importance of something.

~Put down~ means to place something on a surface or to insult.
~Turn down~ means to reject or reduce volume.

sentenceParts.suffix: the company to her successor next year.

cards.correctAnswer: The CEO will hand over the company to her successor next year.
cards.hint: To 'hand over' something means to give control or responsibility for it to someone else.

content.value:
[Hand over] means to transfer power or control.

~Give up~ means to quit.
~Pass on~ means to transmit information or to die.

sentenceParts.prefix: He's very immature; I wish he would

cards.correctAnswer: He's very immature; I wish he would grow up.
cards.hint: Beyond becoming an adult, 'grow up' is often used to tell someone to stop acting in a childish way.

content.value:
[Grow up] means to mature and behave more responsibly.

~Stand up~ means to rise to your feet.
~Show up~ means to arrive.

sentenceParts.suffix: for me while I'm on vacation?

cards.correctAnswer: Could you fill in for me while I'm on vacation?
cards.hint: To 'fill in for' someone means to do their job temporarily while they are away.

content.value:
[Fill in for] is the phrasal verb for substituting for a colleague.

~Take over~ means to take control, often permanently.
~Cover~ is a correct verb but 'fill in for' is the specific phrasal verb.

cards.correctAnswer: The game will hinge on what the referee decides.
cards.hint: To 'hinge on' something means to depend completely on it for the result.

content.value:
[Hinge on] means to be entirely dependent on a single factor.

~Wait for~ means to await.
~Depend on~ is a very good synonym, but 'hinge on' implies that it is the critical, single point of decision.

sentenceParts.prefix: The details of the plan need to be

cards.correctAnswer: The details of the plan need to be spelled out more clearly.
cards.hint: To 'spell out' something means to explain it in great detail, leaving no room for doubt.

content.value:
[Spelled out] means to explain something very explicitly.

~Written down~ means to record on paper.
~Laid out~ means to present in an organized way.

cards.correctAnswer: Don't go back on your promise.
cards.hint: To 'go back on' a promise or agreement means to fail to keep it.

content.value:
[Go back on] means to break a promise.

~Take back~ means to retract a statement.
~Get back~ means to return.

cards.correctAnswer: The police car is going after the speeding vehicle.
cards.hint: To 'go after' someone or something means to pursue or chase them.

content.value:
[Going after] means to chase in order to catch.

~Running to~ is incorrect.
~Following~ means to go behind someone, but doesn't necessarily imply chasing.

cards.correctAnswer: This tradition has been handed down through generations.
cards.hint: To 'hand down' something means to pass it from an older generation to a younger one.

content.value:
[Handed down] means to pass knowledge, traditions, or possessions to the next generation.

~Given away~ means to give for free.
~Passed out~ means to distribute or to faint.

sentenceParts.prefix: She's very shy, but her talent really

cards.correctAnswer: She's very shy, but her talent really shines through on stage.
cards.hint: When a quality 'shines through', it is very noticeable and impressive, even in a difficult situation.

content.value:
[Shines through] means a positive quality is easily seen despite challenges.

~Comes out~ means to be revealed.
~Stands up~ means to rise.

cards.correctAnswer: I can't make out what he's saying.
cards.hint: To 'make out' something means to see, hear, or understand it with difficulty.

content.value:
[Make out] means to discern or understand with difficulty.

~Hear~ and ~understand~ are the general abilities, while 'make out' describes the struggle to do so.

sentenceParts.prefix: The two sides will meet to

cards.correctAnswer: The two sides will meet to draw up a peace agreement.
cards.hint: 'Draw up' means to prepare and write an official document like a contract, plan, or agreement.

content.value:
[Draw up] means to compose a formal document after careful thought.

~Write out~ means to write in full.
~Set up~ means to arrange or establish.
